definitions.definition: to carry or move something from one place to another
definitions.sensetop: take somethingtake something with youtake somebody somethingtake something to somebody/somethingtake something for somebody/something

examples.text: Remember to take your coat when you leave.
I forgot to take my bag with me when I got off the bus.
Shall I take my host family a gift?
Can you take my suit to the dry-cleaner's?
You need to take your laptop to the technician.
Don't forget to take a present for Catherine's new baby.
My things had already been taken to my room.
She took her bags along with her.
Think about what you need to take for the trip.

definitions.definition: to go with somebody from one place to another, especially to guide or lead them
definitions.sensetop: take somebodytake somebody to somethingtake somebody doing somethingtake somebody to do something

examples.text: It's too far to walk—I'll take you by car.
A boy took us to our room.
I'm taking the kids swimming later.
The boys were taken to see their grandparents most weekends.
You should take her home soon.
I asked them if they'd take me with them.

definitions.definition: to make somebody/something go from one level, situation, etc. to another

examples.text: Her energy and talent took her to the top of her profession.
The new loan takes the total debt to $100 000.
I'd like to take my argument a stage further.
He believes he has the skills to take the club forward.
We'll take the matter forward at our next meeting *(= discuss it further)*.

definitions.definition: to need or require a particular amount of time
definitions.sensetop: take somethingtake something to do somethingtake somebody somethingtake somebody something to do somethingtake something for somebody to do something+ adv.

examples.text: The process took about a year.
The journey to the airport takes about half an hour.
**It takes** about half an hour to get to the airport.
That cut is taking a long time to heal.
The official seemed to take hours to examine my passport.
That should only take you ten minutes.
It took her three hours to repair her bike.
examples.contextForm: take somebody something to do something

examples.text: It'll take her time to recover from the illness.
It'll **take time** *(= take a long time)* for her to recover from the illness.
examples.contextForm: take something for somebody to do something

examples.text: I need a shower—I **won't take long**.

definitions.definition: to photograph somebody/something

examples.text: to take a **picture/photo/shot** of somebody/something
to **have your picture/photo taken**

definitions.definition: to use a form of transport, a road, a path, etc. to go to a place

examples.text: to **take the bus/train**
to take a cab/plane
Take the second road on the right.
It's more interesting to take the coast road.
You'll have to take a taxi. There's no other way of getting there.
You fly to Brussels and take the train to Bruges.
We took a ferry across to the island.
We took a bus south to Cairo.
They took the night train to Vienna.

definitions.definition: to put your hands or arms around somebody/something and hold them/it; to reach for somebody/something and hold them/it

examples.text: I passed him the rope and he took it.
Free newspapers: please take one.
Can you take *(= hold)* the baby for a moment?
He took her hand/took her by the hand *(= held her hand, for example to lead her somewhere)*.
She took the child in her arms and kissed him.

definitions.definition: to remove something/somebody from a place or a person

examples.text: Will you take your books off the table?
The sign must be taken down.
He took some keys out of his pocket.
My name had been taken off the list.
She was playing with a knife, so I took it away from her.
She was playing with a knife, so I took it off her.
The new sports centre will **take the pressure off** the old one.

definitions.definition: to remove something without permission or by mistake

examples.text: Someone has taken my scarf.
Did the burglars take anything valuable?
All she had taken was her passport and driving licence.
The storms **took the lives** of 50 people.

definitions.definition: to get something from a particular source
definitions.sensetop: take something from somethingtake something out of something

examples.text: The scientists are taking water samples from the river.
The machine takes its name from its inventor.
Part of her article is taken straight *(= copied)* out of my book.

definitions.definition: to sit down in or use a chair, etc.

examples.text: Are these seats taken?
Come in; **take a seat**.

definitions.definition: to eat, drink, etc. something

examples.text: Do you take sugar in your coffee?
The doctor has given me some medicine to take for my cough.
He started taking drugs *(= illegal drugs)* at college.

definitions.definition: to find out and record something; to write something down

examples.text: The police officer took my name and address.
Did you **take notes** in the class?

definitions.definition: to do an exam or a test

examples.text: When did you take your driving test?

definitions.definition: to study a subject at school, college, etc.

examples.text: She is planning to **take a course** in web design.
Last year I started taking yoga classes.
How many subjects are you taking this year?

definitions.definition: to use a particular course of action in order to deal with or achieve something

examples.text: We need to **take** a different **approach** to the problem.
The government is **taking action** to combat drug abuse.

definitions.definition: used with nouns to say that somebody is doing something, performing an action, etc.

examples.text: to **take a look**
to **take a break**
to **take a shot** at somebody/something
to take a step/walk/stroll
to **take a bath/shower/wash**
to take a bite/drink/sip
to **take a** deep **breath**
We will **take a decision** on the matter next week.
She's taken a nasty fall and has her leg in plaster.
Experts have urged ministers to **take** the necessary **steps** to resolve the issue.

definitions.definition: to test or measure something

examples.text: to take somebody’s temperature
I need to have my blood pressure taken.

definitions.definition: to capture a place or person; to get control of something
definitions.sensetop: take somethingtake something from somebodytake somebody + noun

examples.text: The rebels succeeded in taking the town.
The state has **taken control of** the company.
The militants took the city from government forces.
The rebels took him prisoner.
He was taken prisoner by the rebels.
The bank robbers took several employees hostage.

definitions.definition: to choose, buy or rent something

examples.text: I'll take the grey jacket.
We took a room at the hotel for two nights.

definitions.definition: to buy a newspaper or magazine regularly

examples.text: We take the ‘Express’.

definitions.definition: to accept or receive something

examples.text: If they offer me the job, I'll take it.
She was accused of taking bribes.
I'll take the call in my office.
I **take** full **responsibility** for my actions.
Why should I **take the blame** for somebody else's mistakes?
If you choose deceit, then you must take the consequences of your actions.
If you **take my advice** you'll have nothing more to do with him.
Will you take $10 for the book *(= will you sell it for $10)*?
The store took *(= sold goods worth)* $100 000 last week.

definitions.definition: to act in response to an opportunity

examples.text: When the bus stopped for fuel, we **took the opportunity** to get something to eat.
England failed to **take their chances** and had to settle for a draw.
He isn't afraid to **take risks**.
Take the initiative and fill your life with exciting experiences.

definitions.definition: to accept somebody as a customer, patient, etc.

examples.text: The school doesn't take boys *(= only has girls)*.
The dentist can't take any new patients.

definitions.definition: to experience or be affected by something

examples.text: The school took the full force of the explosion.
Can the ropes **take the strain** *(= not break)*?
The team took a terrible beating.
I'm afraid your husband has taken a turn for the worse.

definitions.definition: to be able to bear something

examples.text: She can't take criticism.
I don't think I can take much more of this heat.
I find his attitude a little hard to take.
It was clear that she wasn't going to take any nonsense.

definitions.definition: to react to something/somebody in a particular way

examples.text: He took the criticism surprisingly well.
These threats are not to be taken lightly.
I wish you'd **take me seriously**.
I was being sarcastic but you took my comment literally.
She took it in the spirit in which it was intended.
Harry took his rejection philosophically.
She took the news of her father's death very badly.
I wanted to be taken seriously as an artist.
They won't take kindly to being ordered about.

definitions.definition: to understand or consider something in a particular way
definitions.sensetop: take somethingtake something as somethingtake something to do something

examples.text: How am I supposed to take that remark?
Taken overall, the project was a success.
She took what he said as a compliment.
What did you take his comments to mean?

definitions.definition: to consider somebody/something to be somebody/something, especially when you are wrong
definitions.sensetop: take somebody/something for somebody/somethingtake somebody/something to be somebody/something

examples.text: Even the experts took the painting for a genuine Van Gogh.
Of course I didn't do it! **What do you take me for** *(= what sort of person do you think I am)*?
I took the man with him to be his father.
I mistakenly took her for the Senator's wife.
He's not the fool you take him for.

definitions.definition: to have a particular feeling, opinion or attitude

examples.text: My parents always **took an interest** in my hobbies.
Don't **take offence** *(= be offended)* at what I said.
I took a dislike to him.
He **takes the view** that children are responsible for their own actions.

definitions.definition: to reduce one number by the value of another
definitions.sensetop: take A (away) (from B)B take away A

examples.text: Take 5 from 12 and you're left with 7.
80 take away 5 is 75.

definitions.definition: used to introduce somebody/something as an example

examples.text: Lots of couples have problems in the first year of marriage. Take Ann and Paul.

definitions.definition: to have or start to have a particular form, position or state

examples.text: Our next class will **take the form** of a debate.
The new president **takes office** in January.
The home side had a chance to **take the lead**.

definitions.definition: to need or require something in order to happen or be done
definitions.sensetop: take somebody/something to do somethingtake something

examples.text: It only takes one careless driver to cause an accident.
It doesn't take much to make her angry.
He didn't take much persuading *(= he was easily persuaded)*.

definitions.definition: to use something in order to work

examples.text: The buses have been adapted to take biofuel.

definitions.definition: to wear a particular size in shoes or clothes

examples.text: What size shoes do you take?

definitions.definition: to have enough space for something/somebody; to be able to hold or contain a particular quantity

examples.text: The bus can take 60 passengers.
The tank takes 50 litres.

definitions.definition: to be the teacher or leader in a class or a religious service

examples.text: The head teacher usually takes us for French.
Mr Perkins took the morning service.

definitions.definition: to go over or around something

examples.text: The horse took the first fence well.
He takes bends much too fast.

definitions.definition: to kick or throw the ball from a fixed or agreed position

examples.text: to take a penalty/free kick/corner

definitions.definition: to use a particular method to find out people’s opinions

examples.text: to take a vote/poll/survey

definitions.definition: to be successful; to work

examples.text: The skin graft failed to take.

definitions.definition: to have or require something when used in a sentence or other structure

examples.text: The verb ‘rely’ takes the preposition ‘on’.

definitions.definition: used to say that you do not care if somebody accepts or rejects your offer
used to say that somebody does not have a strong opinion about something

examples.text: Dancing? I can take it or leave it.

definitions.definition: to have the qualities, ability, etc. needed to be successful
used to say that you cannot trust somebody to behave well in public

examples.text: You haven’t spilled your coffee again! I can’t take you anywhere!

definitions.definition: to accept something/somebody without wishing it/them to be different or without thinking about it/them very much in advance

examples.text: She takes life as it comes.

definitions.definition: to suppose; to assume

examples.text: I take it you won't be coming to the party?

definitions.definition: used to emphasize that what you are going to say is the truth

examples.text: Take it from me—he'll be a millionaire before he's 30.

definitions.definition: to make somebody physically or mentally tired

examples.text: Looking after small children really takes it out of you.

definitions.definition: to decide to do something without asking permission or advice
to need a lot of effort or time; to be very difficult to do
used as an exclamation when you are hitting somebody or attacking them in some other way

wordOrigin: late Old English tacan ‘get (especially by force), capture’, from Old Norse taka ‘grasp, lay hold of’, of unknown ultimate origin.
